w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach vocabulary words associated with describing Korea and the United States. They will learn these words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: Korea, United States, location, traditions, historic places, language, and food
At the completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce these target words associated with Korea and the United States
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use these sets of words in complete sentences
Students will be able to describe traditions, historic places, languages and food in Korea and the United States.
Korea, United States, location, traditions, historic places, language, and food
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about food, languages, locations, traditions, and historic places in Korea and the United States.”
Circle the country of Korea on the world map.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the country of Korea on the world map.
Ask the students: “Do you see the country of Korea?”
Help them find Korea if they need help.
Explain to the students that Korea
Circle the United States on the world map.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the United States on the world map.
Ask the students: “Do you see the United States?”
Help them find United States if they need help.
Explain to the students that United States in in North America.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
“The United States is bigger than Korea”
“Korea is smaller than the United States.”

Ask the students: “How is the map of the United States and Korea similar?”
Remind them that the word similar means alike.
Ask the students: “How is the map of the United States and Korea different?”
Ask the students: “Which country is bigger? Which country is smaller?”
Complete the sentence frame by writing the name of the country
“The Korean flag has blue, red, black, and white.”
“The Korean flag has rectangles and circles.”
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students write the name of the country’s flag on the line.
Explain to the students that this is Korea’s flag.
Ask the students to describe Korea’s flag.
Ask the students: “What colors are in Korea’s flag?”
Ask the students: “What shapes are in Korea’s flag?”
Complete the sentence frame by writing the name of the country
Have the students write the name of the country’s flag on the line.
Explain to the students that this is the United States flag.
Ask the students to describe the American flag.

Circle the name of the American tradition.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle Thanksgiving, the holiday that Americans celebrate.
Ask the students: “Have you ever heard of Thanksgiving? Do you celebrate Thanksgiving?”
Explain to the students that many people eat turkey, mashed potatoes, and pie on Thanksgiving.
Explain to the students that many people thank others on Thanksgiving.
Circle the name of this American tradition.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Ask the students: “Have you ever heard of
American celebrate with fireworks and flags on July 4th
Circle the name of this Korean tradition.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle Seollal, the tradition that Koreans celebrate.
Ask the students: “Have you ever heard of Seollal? Do you celebrate Seollal?”
Ask the students: “How long does this tradition last?”
Ask the students: “How do Koreans celebrate Seollal?”
Circle the name of this Korean tradition.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle Chuseok, the tradition that Koreans celebrate.
Explain to the students that many Koreans go to festivals to celebrate this tradition.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Ask the students: “What is a historical landmark?”
Explain to the students that a historical place to visit in the United States is the Statue of Liberty.
Explain to the students that the Statue of Liberty stands for freedom.
Explain to the students that people can ride in an elevator to the top of the Statue of Liberty.
Ask the students: “Have you ever visited the Statue of Liberty? Would you want to visit the Statue of Liberty in the United States?”
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Explain to the students that another historical place to visit in the United States is the White House in Washington D.C.
Explain to the students that the White House is where the President of the United States lives.
Explain to the students that people can take a tour of the White House.
Ask the students: “Have you ever visited the White House? Would you want to visit the White House in the United States?”
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.

Explain to the students that the
Palace was built in 1405. Explain that this palace is very old.
Explain to the students that kings and queens lived in the palace.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Explain to the students that another famous historical place to visit in Korea is the
Explain to the students that visitors climb 108 steps to get to the temple.
Ask the students: “Have you ever visited the
Temple? Would you ever want to visit the
Circle the names of the languages spoken in the United States.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the names of the languages spoken in the United States.
Explain to the students that there is not just one official language in the United States.
Explain that many Americans speak different languages.
Ask the students: “What are the two main languages spoken in the United States?”
Ask the students: “Do you know any words in English or in Spanish?”
Circle the name of the official language spoken in Korea.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
The official language spoken in Korea is Korean.
Have the students circle the name of the official language spoken in Korea.
Ask the students: “What is the official language spoken in Korea?”
Ask the students: “Do you know any words in Korean?”
Circle the American food that you would like to eat.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the pictures of American food that they would like to eat.
Ask the students: “Have you ever eaten any of these American foods? Which ones?”
Ask the students: “Which foods from America do you like? Which foods from America do you not like?”
Circle the Korean food that you would like to eat.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the pictures of Korean food that they would like to eat.
Ask the students: “Have you ever eaten any of these Korean foods? Which ones?”
Ask the students: “Which foods from Korea do you like? Which foods from Korea do you not like?”
Have the students fill in the missing
Draw a picture of the traditions and foods you like from the United States and Korea.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Ask the students to draw a picture of the traditions and foods they enjoy from the United States and Korea.
Ask the students: “What traditions do you like from the United States?”
Ask the students: “What traditions do you like from Korea?”
Ask the students: “What foods do you like from the United States?”
Ask the students: “What foods do you like from Korea?"
Word Wall Vocabulary Builder Activity – Slide 22
Students will read and spell their new words:
Korea, United States, location, traditions, historic places, language, and food
The teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
